title.children: Number of homes lost in Queensland surpasses 2019 Black Summer bushfire season with more property losses expected

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Danielle Mahe The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland. Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am on Wednesday, following reports a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday reignited. Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions. Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly. "We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said. "It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished. Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating. "I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires." Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Authorities believe arsonist is active in Gold Coast hinterland

children.content: Reporting by Danielle Mahe
The Rural Fire Service believes an arsonist is active on the Gold Coast hinterland.
Crews were called back to the Bonogin Valley at 6:40am
on Wednesday, following reports
a fire they believe was deliberately lit yesterday
reignited.
Six fires were lit along a road on Tuesday, prompting crews to respond rapidly to stop them spreading in the dry, hot conditions.
Chief Superintendent Alan Gillespie said crews managed to get to the fires quickly.
"We were able to scramble resources fairly quickly and they are all out but we will be quite vigilant" Mr Gillespie said.
"It is just incredible that people are doing stupid things like that," he said
A Queensland Fire and Emergency Services (QFES) spokesman said the reignited fire had been extinguished.
Mr Gillespie says they have a number of leads, and that police are investigating.

"I just can't understand the mentality of people who go out and put the community and our firefighters on the line and under risk just for some perverse thrill of seeing vehicles responding to fires."
Queensland Police have been contacted for comment.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season. As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019. Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council, said the loss had had a huge impact on the community. "The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said. "Obviously housing will be our greatest need."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More homes lost in Qld than in 2019 Black Summer

children.content: The loss of homes has had a huge impact on Tara.
(ABC News: Chris Gillette)
The loss of homes around Tara, on Queensland's Western Downs, has now surpassed the total number of homes lost in Queensland during the 2019 Black Summer fire season.

As firefighters have battled blazes in that region for nearly two weeks, with four houses confirmed destroyed in Wallangarra overnight, and 53 destroyed around Tara, for a total of 57, compared to 49 across the state in 2019.
Paul McVeigh, mayor of Western Downs Regional Council,
said the loss had had a huge impact on the community.
"The resilience of our community is very strong … but to be hit with so much devastation is a real challenge," he said.
"Obviously housing will be our greatest need."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Emergency Minister Murray Watt has just given an update on News Breakfast. He says the Victorian firefighters we've been hearing about for a few days are arriving today — and there are 63 of them. "So many Australians have been really pitching in to help each other over the last couple of years. We do need to be careful not to tire people out too early in the season. I've been pleased to be able to tell you that today, we will see 63 Victorian firefighters arrive in Queensland to relieve some of those Queensland firefighters who've been hard at work for the last few weeks. "One of the great things that we're seeing already is a high degree of of interstate cooperation. "Yesterday, we saw a New South Wales aircraft used to help put out some of the fires just over the border in Queensland. We've now got reinforcements coming in from Victoria. And in the next few days, we'll actually welcome some of our friends from New Zealand who are going to provide relief as well. "So I guess that's one of the upsides of these situations is that you do see the best of the Australian character with people helping each other out. And we really thank all of their states for helping out no matter where the events are occurring."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 63 firefighters arriving from Victoria today

children.content: (ABC News: Marton Dobras)
Federal Emergency Minister Murray Watt
has just given an update on News Breakfast. He says the Victorian firefighters we've been hearing about for a few days are arriving today — and there are 63 of them.

"So many Australians have been really pitching in to help each other over the last couple of years. We do need to be careful not to tire people out too early in the season. I've been pleased to be able to tell you that today, we will see 63 Victorian firefighters arrive in Queensland to relieve some of those Queensland firefighters who've been hard at work for the last few weeks.
"One of the great things that we're seeing already is a high degree of of interstate cooperation.
"Yesterday, we saw a
New South Wales aircraft used to help put out some of the fires just over the border in Queensland
. We've now got
reinforcements coming in from Victoria
. And in the next few days, we'll actually welcome some of
our friends from New Zealand who are going to provide relief as well

"So I guess that's one of the upsides of these situations is that you do see the best of the Australian character with people helping each other out. And we really thank all of their states for helping out no matter where the events are occurring."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An interesting report from the Regional Australia Institute and the Commonwealth Bank, based on CBA customer data that covers around 16 million Australians. It turns out that there are still more Aussies moving from the capital cities to the regions than vice versa, with recent years seeing the reversal of a decades long population drain from regional areas. "In the 12 months to September 2023, capital to regional migration accounted for an 11% share of all relocations, compared to 9.1% making the move from the regions to the city," the report found. While newly arrived migrants from overseas overwhelmingly tend to settle in the big capitals, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, existing residents are still exiting the big smoke, especially Sydney. A stunning 80% of net capital city outflows came from Sydney, with a further 27% from Melbourne — the reason those two cities exceed 100% is that Brisbane (11%) and Perth (5%) are still attracting a lot of internal migrants. In terms of where these people are moving, it is often still reasonably close to home, with regional NSW now the most popular destination (39% of people who left a capital city moved there), followed by Queensland (33%) and Victoria (27%). As for exactly where people are moving, Queensland's Sunshine Coast continued to top the list, followed by Greater Geelong and the Gold Coast in a tie for second, then the Fraser Coast in Queensland and Moorabool in regional Victoria. Lake Macquarie in NSW is also among the most popular destinations for previous city dwellers. As for the biggest growth areas for city slickers to move to over the past year, Mackay in northern Queensland topped the list, along with Douglas and the Whitsundays from the same part of the world, with the Snowy Valleys in NSW and Ceduna in South Australia also making the list. "The increasing popularity of these more remote regional growth hotspots, boosted by good regional job prospects and the likelihood of better house prices and availability, has seen some previously popular LGAs come off the boil," the report noted. "For example, LGAs that had amongst the highest net internal migration inflows a year ago (to September 2022) but reported net outflows over the past 12 months include big regional New South Wales centres such as Wagga Wagga, Dubbo, Bathurst, Albury, Lismore, Newcastle, Byron and Orange as well as Mount Gambier in South Australia and West Tamar in Tasmania."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians continue to move from the cities to regions above pre-COVID levels

children.content: An interesting report from the
Regional Australia Institute and the Commonwealth Bank
, based on CBA customer data that covers around 16 million Australians.

It turns out that there are still more Aussies moving from the capital cities to the regions than vice versa, with recent years seeing the reversal of a decades long population drain from regional areas.
"In the 12 months to September 2023, capital to regional migration accounted for an 11% share of all relocations, compared to 9.1% making the move from the regions to the city," the report found.

props.alt: Inflows from capitals to the regions continue to exceed outflows

children.content: Inflows from capitals to the regions continue to exceed outflows
(CBA/RAI)
While newly arrived migrants from overseas overwhelmingly tend to settle in the big capitals, particularly Sydney and Melbourne, existing residents are still exiting the big smoke, especially Sydney.
A stunning
80% of net capital city outflows came from Sydney, with a further 27% from Melbourne
— the reason those two cities exceed 100% is that Brisbane (11%) and Perth (5%) are still attracting a lot of internal migrants.
In terms of where these people are moving, it is often still reasonably close to home, with
regional NSW now the most popular destination (39% of people who left a capital city moved there), followed by Queensland (33%) and Victoria (27%)
As for exactly where people are moving,
Queensland's Sunshine Coast continued to top the list, followed by Greater Geelong and the Gold Coast in a tie for second, then the Fraser Coast in Queensland and Moorabool in regional Victoria
Lake Macquarie in NSW
is also among the most popular destinations for previous city dwellers.
As for the biggest growth areas for city slickers to move to over the past year,
Mackay in northern Queensland topped the list, along with Douglas and the Whitsundays from the same part of the world, with the Snowy Valleys in NSW and Ceduna in South Australia
also making the list.

"The increasing popularity of these more remote regional growth hotspots, boosted by good regional job prospects and the likelihood of better house prices and availability, has seen some previously popular LGAs come off the boil," the report noted.

"For example, LGAs that had amongst the highest net internal migration inflows a year ago (to September 2022) but reported net outflows over the past 12 months include big regional New South Wales centres such as Wagga Wagga, Dubbo, Bathurst, Albury, Lismore, Newcastle, Byron and Orange as well as Mount Gambier in South Australia and West Tamar in Tasmania."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New research from Roy Morgan shows a record high 1.57 million mortgage holders, representing 30.3 per cent of mortgage holders were "at risk" of mortgage stress in the three months to September. The figures for September, which cover the period of the three RBA meetings at which interest rates were left unchanged, represent a new record high, up 7,000 on a month ago. The number of Australians "at risk" of mortgage stress has increased by 766,000 since May 2022 when the RBA began a cycle of interest rate increases. The record high of 35.6 per cent of mortgage holders in mortgage stress was reached in mid-2008, during the global financial crisis. Other data released today by Core Logic, shows national home prices rose 0.9 per cent in October, with the biggest increases were in Perth (+1.6 per cent), Brisbane (+1.4 per cent) and Adelaide (+1.4 per cent). Ray Morgan says the number of mortgage holders considered "extremely at risk" — if even the "interest only" component of a loan is over a certain proportion of household income — is now numbered at 1.43 million (20.5 per cent) which is significantly above the long-term average over the last 15 years of 15.3 per cent. The RBA cash rate is currently at 4.10 per cent — the highest official interest rates since May 2012. Roy Morgan has modelled the impact of two potential RBA interest rate increases of 0.25 per cent in both November and December, which would take the cash rate to 4.6 per cent. It says the numbers of mortgage holders in stress would increase to 1.58 million, or 30.4 per cent — an increase of 8,000 — if the RBA increases interest rates next week. Then, if the RBA raises interest rates by a further 0.25 per cent in December to 4.6 per cent, there will be 31 per cent of mortgage holders, or 1.61 million considered "at risk" — an increase of 39,000. Ray Morgan CEO Michele Levine says the RBA left interest rates unchanged at its last four meetings, but with last month's inflation read higher, "these pressures are adding to calls for the RBA to raise interest rates again and are a key factor for why we have modelled two further interest rate increases". Mortgage stress is measured by when mortgage repayments are greater than a certain percentage of household income. Interest rates are only one of the variables that determines whether a mortgage holder is considered "at risk". The variable that has the largest impact on whether a borrower falls into the "at risk" category is related to household income — which is directly related to employment. "If there is a sharp rise in unemployment, mortgage stress is set to increase even more," Ms Levine said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More than 1.57 million Australians are now 'at risk' of 'mortgage stress'

children.content: New research from
Roy Morgan
shows a record high 1.57 million mortgage holders, representing 30.3 per cent of mortgage holders were "at risk" of mortgage stress in the three months to September.
The figures for September, which cover the period of the three RBA meetings at which interest rates were left unchanged, represent a new record high, up 7,000 on a month ago.
The number of Australians "at risk" of mortgage stress has increased by 766,000 since May 2022 when the RBA began a cycle of interest rate increases.
The record high of 35.6 per cent of mortgage holders in mortgage stress was reached in mid-2008, during the global financial crisis.
Other data released today by Core Logic
, shows national home prices
rose 0.9 per cent in October,
with the biggest increases were in Perth (+1.6 per cent), Brisbane (+1.4 per cent) and Adelaide (+1.4 per cent).
The number of Australians "at risk" of mortgage stress has increased by 766,000 since May 2022.
(ABC News: John Gunn)

Ray Morgan says the number of mortgage holders considered "extremely at risk" — if even the "interest only" component of a loan is over a certain proportion of household income — is now numbered at 1.43 million (20.5 per cent) which is significantly above the long-term average over the last 15 years of 15.3 per cent.
The RBA cash rate is currently at 4.10 per cent — the highest official interest rates since May 2012.
Roy Morgan has modelled the impact of two potential RBA interest rate increases of 0.25 per cent in both November and December, which would take the cash rate to 4.6 per cent.
It says the numbers of mortgage holders in stress would increase to 1.58 million, or 30.4 per cent — an increase of 8,000 — if the RBA increases interest rates next week.

Then, if the RBA raises interest rates by a further 0.25 per cent in December to 4.6 per cent, there will be 31 per cent of mortgage holders, or 1.61 million considered "at risk" — an increase of 39,000.
Ray Morgan
CEO Michele Levine

says the RBA left interest rates unchanged at its last four meetings, but with last month's inflation read higher, "these pressures are adding to calls for the RBA to raise interest rates again and are a key factor for why we have modelled two further interest rate increases".
Mortgage stress is measured by when mortgage repayments are greater than a certain percentage of household income.
Interest rates are only one of the variables that determines whether a mortgage holder is considered "at risk".
The variable that has the largest impact on whether a borrower falls into the "at risk" category is related to household income — which is directly related to employment.
"If there is a sharp rise in unemployment, mortgage stress is set to increase even more," Ms Levine said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's central bank today warned that pockets of financial stress were growing among households struggling with high debt repayments. Interest rates in New Zealand are at 15-year highs of 5.5 per cent as the central bank fights to bring inflation down, and the share of mortgages in arrears is on the increase. "Pockets of stress are likely to grow in the medium term as highly indebted households continue to be tested by higher debt servicing burdens," the Reserve Bank of New Zealand said in its semi-annual Financial Stability Report. "So far, the vast majority of borrowers have been able to manage these increases, but we know some people are struggling and falling behind." The central bank also noted risks to commodity prices from a slowdown in China and added it was closely watching developments in the Middle East.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand's central bank warns of 'pockets of stress'

children.content: New Zealand's central bank today warned that pockets of financial stress were growing among households struggling with high debt repayments.
Interest rates in New Zealand are at 15-year highs of 5.5 per cent as the central bank fights to bring inflation down, and the share of mortgages in arrears is on the increase.

"Pockets of stress are likely to grow in the medium term as highly indebted households continue to be tested by higher debt servicing burdens," the Reserve Bank of New Zealand said in its semi-annual Financial Stability Report.
"So far, the vast majority of borrowers have been able to manage these increases, but we know some people are struggling and falling behind."
The central bank also noted risks to commodity prices from a slowdown in China and added it was closely watching developments in the Middle East.
